newsitem.title: USA: First public launch of U.S. spy satellite held.
newsitem.headline: First public launch of U.S. spy satellite held.

text.p: A U.S. spy satellite successfully lifted off from Vandenberg Air Force Base in southern California on Friday in a public launch that broke the secrecy previously clamped on such events.
The Titan IV rocket and its payload, which remains classified, soared into the sky at 10.04 A.M. PST (1304 EST), Air Force spokesman Major Brad Peck said.
"Everything is going as planned," Peck told Reuters.
It was the first time the U.S. government and its National Reconnaissance Office had acknowledged the launch of a spy satellite.
The agency recently decided to uncloak the launches because keeping them secret has become too costly. But details of the satellite's orbit, mission and technology on board remain top secret.
Since launching the first spy satellite in 1959, the U.S. government has sent over 300 rockets into space carrying surveillance equipment.
